raw_response: {"answer_index": 1, "answer_text": "Sickle cell disease", "confidence": 10, "reasoning": "This 6-year-old African American boy presents with classic symptoms of sickle cell disease: jaundice (from hemolysis), normocytic anemia, elevated reticulocyte count (compensatory erythropoiesis), and severe bone pain (vaso-occlusive crisis). The peripheral smear shows sickled cells and Howell-Jolly bodies (nuclear remnants), indicating functional asplenia. The hemoglobin electrophoresis (not shown here, but implied by the context) would show predominance of HbS. Sickle cell trait is usually asymptomatic. Hemoglobin F is present in infants and decreases with age. HbC disease is less common and presents differently. The evidence is consistent with sickle cell disease.", "evidence_quality": "normal"}
